metadata.sermon_start_end: We have on our plate today two lepers and a Psalm. I Consider the cases of the two lepers. The first leper is Syrian commander, Naaman. This means he was a high-ranking general in the Syrian army, a political general . . . but also an enemy of Israel. [...] The ex-lepers know that the world is open to divine compassion. God is not yet finished with the healing work. And, dear sisters and brothers, neither are we!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's primary formal requirement by using three distinct passages (2 Kings, Mark, and Psalm 30) rather than one specific pericope. It treats the Bible as a collection of 'reference points' or 'themes' (leprosy as metaphor) rather than recreating a specific text into a current word. The unique 'NOWHERE else' quality of a single text is lost in thematic synthesis.
quotes: We have on our plate today two lepers and a Psalm.
leprosy in the Bible becomes a metaphor for all kinds of diseases and malfunctions.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one passage—either the Naaman narrative, the Markan healing, or Psalm 30—and extract its specific, unique claim rather than harmonizing them under a general theme of 'healing juices'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic narrative exposition of the Naaman and Markan accounts, but it remains at the level of storytelling. The theological depth of the 'religious history of Israel' or the specific 'theology of the biblical books' (e.g., the specific function of the cultic laws regarding purity) is mentioned but not rigorously explored.
quotes: It made them ritually impure. It barred them from church and from public events.
The story does not tell us how the healing happened, wanting us only to be amazed at the cure.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis by moving beyond narrative summary. Explore the specific Hebrew/Greek nuances of 'cleansing' versus 'healing' to ground the sermon in the original context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its list of modern 'leprosies' (HIV, addiction, failed investments), which meets Dekker's demand for humanities-based knowledge and zeitgeist awareness. However, it risks turning the text into a mere metaphor for general human struggle.
quotes: Some of you may have an addiction that has power over you, a lot like leprosy.
Some of you have made poor investments and are very close to the edge, a lot like leprosy.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid turning the biblical text into a 'metaphor' for everything. The application should flow from the specific text's demand, not just a list of modern problems categorized under 'L'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a block structure: Exposition (I, II, III), then Application (IV), then Synthesis (V, VI). This separation is exactly what Dekker warns against, as it makes the 'present' of revelation less urgent.
quotes: Now I know this is not your story. I assume that you are like me...
Well, take that list, extend it toward yourself.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the modern 'leprosies' directly into the reading of the text so the hearer is 'expounded' alongside the biblical characters.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The structure of misery (leprosy/stigma), redemption (healing/Jesus' touch), and gratitude (the song/proclamation) is present. It correctly identifies misery as 'misery before God' (ritual impurity), though it leans heavily on psychological comfort.
quotes: The Psalm performs the standard drama of trouble: I will be OK; I am suddenly not OK; I prayed to God for healing; I am healed and praise God.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'redemption' part by emphasizing that it is an act of God's grace outside of man, rather than just 'healing juices' that are 'under way'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is the weakest point. The sermon suggests a universal 'healing juice' and 'divine compassion' without the seriousness of the 'two ways' or the possibility of being lost. The 'lost' are merely 'not yet healed'.
quotes: The promise is that the healing will come.
It is rather a performance of transformation, of old made new, of lost found, of dead made alive.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the 'seriousness of choice' mentioned in Thesis 6. What happens if one refuses the 'Jordan' or refuses to come to Jesus? The sermon lacks the 'narrow way' tension.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is presented as the 'healing agent' and the 'successor to Elisha'. While he is the telos, the sermon flirts with a semi-liberal view of Jesus as a model for our own 'healing work' rather than the ontological Savior (the two natures).
quotes: Jesus sees himself as a successor to Elisha in being God’s healing agent in the world.
God is not yet finished with the healing work. And, dear sisters and brothers, neither are we!
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Clarify that Christ is not just a 'reference point' or 'agent' but the Lord from whom alone grace flows. Ensure the 'work' is primarily His, not ours.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14.5 minutes, the sermon falls significantly short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the theological and exegetical exploration of the text to meet the 20-minute threshold, allowing the 'dogma to sleep' more deeply through thorough exposition.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails the formal definition of a sermon by Dekker's standards. It is a thematic speech about 'healing' and 'leprosy' using multiple texts as illustrations, rather than an exposition of one specific passage. It lacks the 'two ways' tension, opting for a general optimism about 'healing juices' and human collusion in divine work.
strengths: Concrete application to modern social and personal 'stigmas'.
Clear movement through the triad of misery, redemption, and gratitude.
Effective use of narrative to engage the hearer's imagination.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes), preventing theological depth.
Lack of a single, specific biblical pericope as the absolute starting point.
Absence of the 'two ways' (the possibility of being lost) and a somewhat anthropocentric conclusion regarding 'our work'.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an engaging religious speech, but it is not a sermon according to Dekker’s criteria. It prioritizes a general biblical 'idea' over the specific, unique word of a single text and lacks the necessary breadth and existential gravity (the two ways) required for the right proclamation of the Gospel.
